channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Edward C. Stone obituary: physicist who guided Voyager probes to interstellar space
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02285-w

Space scientist who took humanity on a tour of the Solar System and beyond, in a journey of discovery like no other.
item.dc:title: Edward C. Stone obituary: physicist who guided Voyager probes to interstellar space
item.dc:creator: Alan C. Cummings

item.title: How mud brought France and England together — 150 years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02229-4

Artificial daylight lacks commercial interest, and a geologist’s thirst for knowledge kickstarts the bid for the Channel Tunnel, in our weekly dip into Nature’s archive.
item.dc:title: How mud brought France and England together — 150 years ago

item.content:encoded:

To explain biological sex, look to evolution

item.title: Storm-chasing seabirds served supper by cyclones
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02201-2

The ocean-going Desertas petrel often follows storms for days over thousands of kilometres.
item.dc:title: Storm-chasing seabirds served supper by cyclones

item.title: More studies needed on how climate change affects exercise health benefits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02249-0

More studies needed on how climate change affects exercise health benefits
item.dc:title: More studies needed on how climate change affects exercise health benefits
item.dc:creator: Zhenxiang Guo

item.title: Vaccines save lives: how can uptake be increased?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02224-9

Strategies for public engagement need to be rigorously tested around the world to maximize the potential of immunization.
item.dc:title: Vaccines save lives: how can uptake be increased?

item.title: Iran elects heart surgeon as president: scientists are hopeful
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02262-3

Researchers say unexpected victory for Masoud Pezeshkian could spell improvements to human rights, investment in science and academic freedom - if Iran's top leaders give him space to act.
item.dc:title: Iran elects heart surgeon as president: scientists are hopeful
item.dc:creator: Michele Catanzaro

item.title: If bird flu sparks a human pandemic, your past immunity could help
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02170-6

Older populations might be more protected than younger ones because of exposure to ‘matched’ strains during childhood, but an H5N1 pandemic is likely to take a major toll all the same.
item.dc:title: If bird flu sparks a human pandemic, your past immunity could help
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Canada just hiked PhD and postdoc pay — here’s how to get your country to do it, too
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02227-6

Walkouts, petitions and tweets: how a grass-roots movement led by students, postdocs and tenured academics radically changed government policy on science funding.
item.dc:title: Canada just hiked PhD and postdoc pay — here’s how to get your country to do it, too
item.dc:creator: Kaitlin Kharas

item.title: How PhD students and other academics are fighting the mental-health crisis in science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02225-8

Universities and institutions across the globe are exploring unique initiatives to help their students and staff cope with the stress of research.
item.dc:title: How PhD students and other academics are fighting the mental-health crisis in science
item.dc:creator: Shannon Hall

item.title: Chiral perovskites deliver spin control to a conventional semiconductor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02263-2

The integration of a chiral halide perovskite semiconductor into a light-emitting diode (LED) structure made from a III–V optoelectronic semiconductor creates a spin-LED that achieves 15% circularly polarized emission at room temperature without a magnetic field — a potential boon for spintronics and other spin‑based technologies.
item.dc:title: Chiral perovskites deliver spin control to a conventional semiconductor

item.title: Ultracold molecules that interact from afar form elusive quantum state
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02134-w

A gas of molecules that interact over long distances has been cooled to mere nanokelvins, resulting in the emergence of a state known as a Bose–Einstein condensate — the first of its kind in this type of molecular system.
item.dc:title: Ultracold molecules that interact from afar form elusive quantum state
item.dc:creator: Lauriane Chomaz

item.title: Huge neutrino detector sees first hints of particles from exploding stars
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02221-y

Japan’s Super-Kamiokande observatory could be seeing evidence of neutrinos from supernovae across cosmic history.
item.dc:title: Huge neutrino detector sees first hints of particles from exploding stars
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Why I work to revive the Tasmanian tiger
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02228-5

Andrew Pask develops genetic sequencing techniques for marsupials — including an apex predator that was hunted to death in the twentieth century.
item.dc:title: Why I work to revive the Tasmanian tiger
item.dc:creator: Margaret Simons

item.title: How can I break into industry if my CV keeps disappearing into a black hole?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02203-0

An application needs to stand out from the crowd and avoid being filtered out by automated hiring systems. Nature spoke to industry experts to get their tips on how to make sure your CV gets seen.
item.dc:title: How can I break into industry if my CV keeps disappearing into a black hole?
item.dc:creator: Miles Lizak

item.title: Scientists relieved by far-right defeat in French election — but they still face uncertainty
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02260-5

With no party winning an outright majority, the vote’s implications for research are unclear.
item.dc:title: Scientists relieved by far-right defeat in French election — but they still face uncertainty
item.dc:creator: Barbara Casassus

item.title: Can AI be superhuman? Flaws in top gaming bot cast doubt
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02218-7

Building robust AI systems that always outperform people might be harder than thought, say researchers who studied Go-playing bots.
item.dc:title: Can AI be superhuman? Flaws in top gaming bot cast doubt
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hutson

item.title: ITER delay: what it means for nuclear fusion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02247-2

The world’s biggest fusion-energy experiment is likely to be beaten to its goals by other projects — but the massive reactor still has value, say scientists.
item.dc:title: ITER delay: what it means for nuclear fusion
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: COVID tsar Patrick Vallance appointed UK science minister
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02261-4

Labour Prime Minister Keir Starmer has placed several experts who aren’t politicians into government posts.
item.dc:title: COVID tsar Patrick Vallance appointed UK science minister
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney
Sarah Wild

item.title: Ex-Meta scientists debut gigantic AI protein design model
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02214-x

EvolutionaryScale’s protein language model — among the largest AI models in biology — has created new fluorescent proteins and won big investment.
item.dc:title: Ex-Meta scientists debut gigantic AI protein design model
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: How conspiracies took root in our culture
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02226-7

UFO hunters and anti-vaxxers might seem like modern phenomena, but they both take inspiration from a little-known anti-science movement.
item.dc:title: How conspiracies took root in our culture
item.dc:creator: Michael Shermer

item.title: Daily briefing: 15-minute reaction turns old clothes into useful molecules
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02269-w

A chemical-processing technique breaks down polyester fabrics, the world’s oldest inhabited termite mounds and a COVID tsar is named UK science minister.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: 15-minute reaction turns old clothes into useful molecules
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Harrowing trends: how endangered-species researchers find hope in the dark
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02205-y

When data collection can be damaging, conservation scientists must balance ethical trade-offs between interference and inaction.
item.dc:title: Harrowing trends: how endangered-species researchers find hope in the dark
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: Blooming plants and sunken cities, Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02220-z

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: Blooming plants and sunken cities, Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: What causes migraines? Study of ‘brain blackout’ offers clues
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02222-x

The blinding headaches are poorly understood — a mouse study suggests that the content of spinal fluid is a trigger for pain.
item.dc:title: What causes migraines? Study of ‘brain blackout’ offers clues
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: “Who am I if not a scientist?” How to find identity and purpose in retirement
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02246-3

How do scientists define themselves when they leave paid employment after an all-consuming career in academic research?
item.dc:title: “Who am I if not a scientist?” How to find identity and purpose in retirement
item.dc:creator: Julie Gould

item.title: Kyoto review: ‘thrilling’ play shows fight for landmark climate treaty
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02251-6

Drama behind the scenes at the Kyoto Protocol negotiations is laid bare in a major theatrical production.
item.dc:title: Kyoto review: ‘thrilling’ play shows fight for landmark climate treaty
item.dc:creator: Peter Stott

item.title: UK election: scientists welcome Labour’s landslide win
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02219-6

Struggling universities should be near the top of the new government’s agenda, say researchers.
item.dc:title: UK election: scientists welcome Labour’s landslide win
item.dc:creator: Jonathan O'Callaghan

item.title: Daily briefing: Spinal fluid causes aural migraine pain, suggests research in mice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02257-0

Brain activity heralded by blind spots, flashes and other migraine ‘auras’ seems to trigger a change in cerebrospinal fluid. Plus, a ‘frog sauna’ protects against killer fungal disease and the benefits of full-body, continuous wearable ultrasound.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Spinal fluid causes aural migraine pain, suggests research in mice
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Daily briefing: Heavy-lift rocket restores Europe’s access to space
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02240-9

After years of delays, Europe’s heavy-lift launcher Ariane 6 is scheduled for an inaugural flight next week. Plus, mysterious ancient humans hunted hyenas to thrive on top of the world and how individual brain cells encode the meaning of words.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Heavy-lift rocket restores Europe’s access to space
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Faecal transplants can treat some cancers — but probably won’t ever be widely used
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02212-z

Gut microbiota could be crucial to the success or failure of immunotherapy. Donated stool might give oncologists a way to tip the balance, but the real excitement lies in what comes next.
item.dc:title: Faecal transplants can treat some cancers — but probably won’t ever be widely used
item.dc:creator: Liam Drew

item.title: ‘Chemical recycling’: 15-minute reaction turns old clothes into useful molecules
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02210-1

Fast fashion creates millions of tonnes of waste each year — could clever chemistry help to tackle the problem?
item.dc:title: ‘Chemical recycling’: 15-minute reaction turns old clothes into useful molecules
item.dc:creator: Helena Kudiabor

item.title: ‘All things that wander in the heavens’: how I swapped my ivory tower for the world of science fiction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02211-0

Astrobiologist and writer Seven Rasmussen reflects on the craft and complexities of being a scientist-storyteller.
item.dc:title: ‘All things that wander in the heavens’: how I swapped my ivory tower for the world of science fiction
item.dc:creator: Fayth Tan

item.title: Give UK science the overhaul it urgently needs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02197-9

Five scholars share their science-policy priorities for the incoming government as it faces urgent challenges in tackling climate change, health, inequality and more.
item.dc:title: Give UK science the overhaul it urgently needs
item.dc:creator: Marie Claire Brisbois
Furaha Asani
Jon Agar
Yacine Rezgui
Maria Nedeva

item.title: Japan’s scientists demand more money for basic science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00942-8

Petition representing hundreds of thousands of researchers in Japan calls for an increase in cash to boost competitiveness.
item.dc:title: Japan’s scientists demand more money for basic science
item.dc:creator: Anna Ikarashi

item.title: How do you make salty water drinkable? The hunt for fresh solutions to a briny problem
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02073-6

Unconventional methods for desalination could create more drinking water, help many industries to deal with problematic brines and increase lithium supplies for batteries.
item.dc:title: How do you make salty water drinkable? The hunt for fresh solutions to a briny problem
item.dc:creator: XiaoZhi Lim

item.title: Observation of the scaling dimension of fractional quantum Hall anyons
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07727-z

Observation of the scaling dimension of fractional quantum Hall anyons
item.dc:title: Observation of the scaling dimension of fractional quantum Hall anyons

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07595-7

Author Correction: Chemoproteomic discovery of a covalent allosteric inhibitor of WRN helicase

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07696-3

Author Correction: Microglia regulate central nervous system myelin growth and integrity

item.title: Fake jewellery from the Stone Age looks like the real deal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02139-5

‘Amber’ beads dating to the Neolithic period, lasting from the fifth to the third millennium BC, are actually mollusc shells coated with resin and natural pigments.
item.dc:title: Fake jewellery from the Stone Age looks like the real deal

item.title: Geographical migration and fitness dynamics of Streptococcus pneumoniae
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07626-3

Mathematical modelling of 15 years of data from South Africa reveals the spread and vaccine-driven changes in fitness and antimicrobial resistance of Streptococcus pneumoniae.
item.dc:title: Geographical migration and fitness dynamics of Streptococcus pneumoniae

item.title: Electron holography observation of individual ferrimagnetic lattice planes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07673-w

The magnetic fields of an individual lattice plane inside materials with a non-uniform structure were observed under magnetic-field-free conditions by electron holography.
item.dc:title: Electron holography observation of individual ferrimagnetic lattice planes

item.title: Molecular definition of the endogenous Toll-like receptor signalling pathways
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07614-7

Myddosomes, in which MyD88 forms barrel-like scaffold structures for effector protein recruitment and activation, contain proteins that act at all stages and regulate all effector responses of the TLR signalling pathways.
item.dc:title: Molecular definition of the endogenous Toll-like receptor signalling pathways
item.dc:creator: Daniel Fisch
Tian Zhang
He Sun
Weiyi Ma
Yunhao Tan
Steven P. Gygi
Darren E. Higgins
Jonathan C. Kagan

item.title: Expanding chemistry through in vitro and in vivo biocatalysis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07506-w

This Review considers developments in enzymes, biosynthetic pathways and cellular engineering that enable their use in catalysis for new chemistry and beyond.
item.dc:title: Expanding chemistry through in vitro and in vivo biocatalysis
item.dc:creator: Elijah N. Kissman
Max B. Sosa
Douglas C. Millar
Edward J. Koleski
Kershanthen Thevasundaram
Michelle C. Y. Chang

item.title: Giant stem tetrapod was apex predator in Gondwanan late Palaeozoic ice age
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07572-0

A study describes a new giant stem tetrapod, Gaiasia jennyae, from high-palaeolatitude early Permian-aged deposits in Namibia that challenges current hypotheses of early tetrapod evolution.
item.dc:title: Giant stem tetrapod was apex predator in Gondwanan late Palaeozoic ice age
item.dc:creator: Claudia A. Marsicano
Jason D. Pardo
Roger M. H. Smith
Adriana C. Mancuso
Leandro C. Gaetano
Helke Mocke

item.title: Human degradation of tropical moist forests is greater than previously estimated
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07629-0

A global survey on the magnitude and persistence of moist forest cover change and canopy height following degradation using satellite remote sensing data finds that the effects are substantial and persist for decades.
item.dc:title: Human degradation of tropical moist forests is greater than previously estimated
item.dc:creator: C. Bourgoin

item.title: Targeting pericentric non-consecutive motifs for heterochromatin initiation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07640-5

Zinc-finger proteins ZNF512 and ZNF512B are shown to target pericentric DNA through a conserved mechanism that depends on their atypical long linkers, providing insight into how constitutive heterochromatin formation is initiated across various species.
item.dc:title: Targeting pericentric non-consecutive motifs for heterochromatin initiation
item.dc:creator: Runze Ma
Yan Zhang
Jing Zhang
Pinqi Zhang
Zeqi Liu
Yiming Fan
Hao-Tian Wang
Zhuqiang Zhang
Bing Zhu

item.title: Narrative cave art in Indonesia by 51,200 years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07541-7

A cave art scene at Leang Karampuang, Indonesia, dated to at least 51,200 years ago using laser-ablation uranium-series imaging, depicts human-like figures interacting with a pig.
item.dc:title: Narrative cave art in Indonesia by 51,200 years ago
item.dc:creator: Adhi Agus Oktaviana

item.title: Spike deep mutational scanning helps predict success of SARS-CoV-2 clades
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07636-1

Pseudovirus-based SARS-CoV-2 spike deep mutational scanning is used to measure how mutations across the spikes affect ACE2 binding, cell entry or escape from human sera, producing data that could enable better prediction of viral evolution.
item.dc:title: Spike deep mutational scanning helps predict success of SARS-CoV-2 clades
item.dc:creator: Bernadeta Dadonaite

item.title: Dirac mass induced by optical gain and loss
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07664-x

By using a photonic synthetic lattice, it can be experimentally demonstrated that Dirac masses can be induced by means of non-Hermitian perturbations based on optical gain and loss.
item.dc:title: Dirac mass induced by optical gain and loss
item.dc:creator: Letian Yu
Haoran Xue
Ruixiang Guo
Eng Aik Chan

Cesare Soci

Y. D. Chong

item.title: Inhibition of M. tuberculosis and human ATP synthase by BDQ and TBAJ-587
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07605-8

Cryogenic electron microscopy structures of Mycobacterium tuberculosis ATP synthase and human ATP synthase bound to the anti-tuberculosis drug bedaquiline or its analogue TBAJ-587 shed light on drug binding and could lead to new treatments for tuberculosis.
item.dc:title: Inhibition of M. tuberculosis and human ATP synthase by BDQ and TBAJ-587
item.dc:creator: Yuying Zhang

item.title: Evidence of striped electronic phases in a structurally modulated superlattice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07589-5

Evidence of modulated metallic and superconducting states stemming from an incommensurate structural stripe motif is reported in the bulk van der Waals superlattice SrTa2S5.
item.dc:title: Evidence of striped electronic phases in a structurally modulated superlattice
item.dc:creator: A. Devarakonda
A. Chen
S. Fang
D. Graf
M. Kriener

J. G. Checkelsky

item.title: Semantic encoding during language comprehension at single-cell resolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07643-2

By tracking the activity of individual neurons using microarrays and Neuropixels probes, a study examines the representation of linguistic meaning, at the single-cell level, during natural speech processing in humans.
item.dc:title: Semantic encoding during language comprehension at single-cell resolution
item.dc:creator: Mohsen Jamali
Benjamin Grannan

item.title: Middle and Late Pleistocene Denisovan subsistence at Baishiya Karst Cave
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07612-9

Zooarchaeological and proteomic analyses of bones from Baishiya Karst Cave on the Tibetan Plateau identify a hominin rib specimen, and provide insight into the ways Denisovans interacted with their surrounding environment and made use of animal resources.
item.dc:title: Middle and Late Pleistocene Denisovan subsistence at Baishiya Karst Cave

item.title: Imaging tunable Luttinger liquid systems in van der Waals heterostructures
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07596-6

Layer-stacking domain walls in van der Waals heterostructures form a broadly tunable Luttinger liquid system, including both isolated and coupled arrays.
item.dc:title: Imaging tunable Luttinger liquid systems in van der Waals heterostructures

item.title: A µ-opioid receptor modulator that works cooperatively with naloxone
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07587-7

A newly discovered negative allosteric modulator of the µ-opioid receptor works together with naloxone to potently block opioid agonist signalling with reduced adverse effects.
item.dc:title: A µ-opioid receptor modulator that works cooperatively with naloxone
item.dc:creator: Evan S. O’Brien

item.title: The cortical amygdala consolidates a socially transmitted long-term memory
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07632-5

Experiments in mice show that brain circuitry centred on the posteromedial nucleus of the cortical amygdala has a key role in consolidating socially transmitted long-term memories.
item.dc:title: The cortical amygdala consolidates a socially transmitted long-term memory
item.dc:creator: Zhihui Liu
Wenfei Sun
Yi Han Ng
Hua Dong
Stephen R. Quake
Thomas C. Südhof

item.title: NBS1 lactylation is required for efficient DNA repair and chemotherapy resistance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07620-9

Lactylation of NBS1 by TIP60 promotes homologous recombination-driven DNA repair and resistance to chemotherapy in cancer cells and links altered cancer cell metabolism to increase genome stability.
item.dc:title: NBS1 lactylation is required for efficient DNA repair and chemotherapy resistance
item.dc:creator: Hengxing Chen
Yun Li

item.title: Adenosine signalling to astrocytes coordinates brain metabolism and function
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07611-w

This study explores how adenosine A2B receptors can act as astrocytic sensors of brain metabolic activity and how cAMP signalling in astrocytes may support core brain functions such as sleep and memory.
item.dc:title: Adenosine signalling to astrocytes coordinates brain metabolism and function
item.dc:creator: Shefeeq M. Theparambil

item.title: 3D printable elastomers with exceptional strength and toughness
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07588-6

Three-dimensional photo-printable resin chemistry yields an elastomer with tensile strength of 94.6  MPa and toughness of 310.4  MJ  m−3, both of which far exceed that of any three-dimensional printed elastomer.
item.dc:title: 3D printable elastomers with exceptional strength and toughness
item.dc:creator: Zizheng Fang

item.title: An anti-CRISPR that pulls apart a CRISPR–Cas complex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07642-3

AcrIF25 inhibits the type I-F CRISPR–Cas system by disassembling its ribonucleoprotein effector complex without an external energy source.
item.dc:title: An anti-CRISPR that pulls apart a CRISPR–Cas complex
item.dc:creator: Chantel N. Trost

Yurima Hidalgo-Reyes
Beatrice C. M. Fung
Jiuyu Wang
Wang-Ting Lu
Karen L. Maxwell
Yanli Wang
Alan R. Davidson

item.title: Kinetic features dictate sensorimotor alignment in the superior colliculus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07619-2

Motor units in the superior colliculus of mice exhibit poorly defined representation of static visual fields and instead rely largely on kinetic visual features to link visual inputs to behavioural outcomes.
item.dc:title: Kinetic features dictate sensorimotor alignment in the superior colliculus
item.dc:creator: Ana González-Rueda
Kristopher Jensen
Mohammadreza Noormandipour

Marco Tripodi

item.title: Powerful Ariane 6 rocket poised to restore Europe’s access to space
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02191-1

After years of delays, the heavy-lift launcher is finally ready to send major scientific missions into space.
item.dc:title: Powerful Ariane 6 rocket poised to restore Europe’s access to space
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Atom-swap chemistry speeds synthesis of compounds for drug discovery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02017-0

Reactions have been discovered that selectively transform nitrogen-containing rings, called pyrimidines, into various other ring systems — enabling rapid preparation of compound libraries for pharmaceutical research.
item.dc:title: Atom-swap chemistry speeds synthesis of compounds for drug discovery
item.dc:creator: Ángel Rentería-Gómez
Osvaldo Gutierrez

item.title: Eating habits of Denisovans on the Tibetan Plateau revealed
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02160-8

The discovery of a rib fragment from Baishiya Karst Cave greatly extends the presence of Denisovan hominins on the Tibetan Plateau. In-depth analyses of fossilized animal bones from the same site show that Denisovans made full use of the available animal resources.
item.dc:title: Eating habits of Denisovans on the Tibetan Plateau revealed

item.title: Last year’s summer was the warmest in 2,000 years
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 July 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02057-6

A record spanning two millennia of Northern Hemisphere summer temperatures has revealed the extent to which 2023 was anomalously hot. The finding is a striking confirmation of warming since the pre-industrial period.
item.dc:title: Last year’s summer was the warmest in 2,000 years
item.dc:creator: Gabriele C. Hegerl
Katherine L. Taylor
